data.title: THE DAILY SHOW WITH JON STEWART PRESENTS AMERICA (THE BOOK): A Citizen's Guide to Democracy Inaction: Stewart, Jon, The Writers of The Daily Show: 9780446691864: Amazon.com: Books
data.meta_description: THE DAILY SHOW WITH JON STEWART PRESENTS AMERICA (THE BOOK): A Citizen's Guide to Democracy Inaction [Stewart, Jon, The Writers of The Daily Show] on Amazon.com. *FREE* shipping on qualifying offers. THE DAILY SHOW WITH JON STEWART PRESENTS AMERICA (THE BOOK): A Citizen's Guide to Democracy Inaction
data.text:
Customers find the humor insightful, accurate, and hilarious. They also mention that the book contains dozens of hilarious drawings, photographs, quotations, and the section on the judicial system is particularly hilarious.

"...All in all, this book has a lot of funny eye candy to offer that will have you laughing out loud, probably a little pissed off..." Read more

"...This is a very funny book, and a light read that could be made deeper if you want to take its more serious issues to heart...." Read more

Customers find the book fairly informative, entertaining, and great for history or political buffs. They also appreciate the silly but profoundly critical discussion questions, diagrams, and smart-ass footnotes. Readers also mention that the teacher edition is genius and the book is wittily on-target historical satire.

"...However, I think the book is interesting from the perspective that a satirized American might actually believe the facts listed...." Read more

"...bemused disgust that I enjoy and appreciate, and it's interesting to see what gets edited and what doesn't, but those things alone are not enough to..." Read more

Customers find the book brilliant and well organized. They also appreciate the pictures, diagrams, and neat little ideas.

"...Laid out like a textbook, the book is divided into chapters on democracy before America, the founding fathers, the presidency, congress, the..." Read more

"...There is a also a lovely map that shows (in the familiar boardgame fashion) how to become President, and how to stay President once you are there...." Read more

"...The great thing about this book is how well it's made. It's cleverly designed to mimic the feel of a high school textbook and is very well made...." Read more

Customers find the writing style sharp, thoughtful, and light-hearted. They also describe the book as well-written, sassy, and a mock social studies text book. Readers also mention that Stewart is an extremely intelligent man and his use of humor shows.

"...It's sad, but it's presented with such sharp wit that you take the medicine willingly...." Read more

"...I love the textbook style of the book as there are a lot of jokes that the writers were able to mine out of it including all the side notes,..." Read more

"...Thankfully, America (The Book) is a mock social studies text book, rife with all sorts of charts, graphs, and photos, that looks at American..." Read more

"A good gift. From the moment my stepbrother opened the box a smile radiated outwards. I couldn't help reading through as well...." Read more

"If you are a fan of Jon Stewart this is a must buy. Great to give as a gift...." Read more

Customers have mixed opinions about the readability of the book. Some find it easy to read, with Stewart doing a great job narrating and entertaining them with insightful candor. However, others find the print tiny and difficult to read. They also mention that the book is entirely like a textbook and gets boring to read quickly.

"...This is a very funny book, and a light read that could be made deeper if you want to take its more serious issues to heart...." Read more

"...To put this book over the top, it is ENTIRELY like a TEXTBOOK!..." Read more

"...It is an easy read seeing as how there is no plot so you can actually pick it up at any point and still be able to "get it."..." Read more

"There was no real substance to this book and difficult to read due to the small size print and the way it was laid out...." Read more

Customers are mixed about the factual accuracy of the book. Some find it informative, truthful, and genuine, while others say that it contains completely false bits of information and absurd descriptions of past events that never happened.

"...Some of the facts are true, some are half-truths, some are outright lies, and the fact that the average reader cannot always tell the difference..." Read more
